review_title: We were asked to write reviews…
job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Columbus, OH
pros:
So many clients to serve, all different ages and back grounds! They make it worth it.
Weekly supervision meetings with supervisors, good for license progression if that is your goal. Lots of trainings available, good for CEU’s.
Benefits are good.
You create your own schedule and can flex your time/days off as needed. Both telehealth and in person meetings are available now which creates more flexibility for scheduling.
cons:
My own mental health is in ruins because of this job.
Salary is low for both licensed and unlicensed staff. You can get a bonus based on an unrealistic productivity system. Made to feel like a number rather than a person. 
They increased productivity during the pandemic from 52% to 58%, but client engagement got harder due to telehealth so achieving productivity is often unrealistic. Productivity is based solely on billable time with clients rather than all the other work that goes into your job description. E.G, mandatory trainings, monthly meetings, calling to schedule clients, paperwork, creating session plans, ANYTHING that takes up time in your day but they can’t get $$ for, does not contribute to productivity. I am constantly stressed. 
In order to make productivity, you are expected to be available whenever the client is available. This means worker longer days (I worked 10 hour days for a while) but not overtime is allowed. So I would type notes “off the clock”.
They recently started a contract to assist with crisis assessments and expect people to sign up to complete assessments. You have to clear your schedule on the off chance you get a call, meaning you miss out on productivity from actual clients. They make this seem “like a game”, if you don’t voluntarily sign up, they will “pick a winner” to do it instead. 
You’re expected to always be available for clients, even on days off. 
They advertise a minimum of 2 weeks vacation, but aren’t guaranteed it. You have to accrue it throughout the year; so 1 week per 6 months. You don’t ‘earn’ more until you have been here for 3 years. 
I am lucky to have a nice supervisor, but other supervisors can be rude, condescending and very cliquey. Upper management doesn’t seem to care about us “lowly” workers and won’t change a thing. There’s a high turnover of staff here for a reason, I’m not sure how I lasted so long.

pros: Work is engaging, dynamic. I had good support from my supervisor, and lost of clients.
cons: Company is very revenue oriented, however they still wildly underpay its workers. Bonuses are not a substitute for living wage.

review_title: One review just to leave a review

cons: The billing Dept ruined my mental health and this agency’s entire purpose is to support mental health of clients! I have never felt so depressed just because of who I worked for. Management wise. Leaving ogs was necessary to better the damage done to my family life by my unhappiness.

job_title: Community Mental Health in Cleveland, OH
pros: A few really nice people to say hello and share the day
cons:
Management is out of touch  and lacking the insight to see how to make employees 
feel empowered, with the acknowledgement. They must actually believe it. Management say there is paid vacation but that is not true. Workers must charge Medicare 50% on any day you are paid for, but if I take a day off I am still required to biil those hours Add some addition stress and bill double and work outside of. Management knows all of this. Management does not have to do double paperwork or reports.

pros: There are clients that want to make progress and improve themselves despite devastating trauma and stress.  They will steal your heart.
cons: There are clients whose sole purpose is to hurt each other and the staff.  Injuries are commonplace.  Many "Treatment Specialists" spend their time on their phones ignoring h clients.  Management has been unable to stop this because they are desperate to fill positions due to massive turnover.  Residential Treatment is shrinking, not due to a lack of clients, but due to dwindling staff rosters.  Those that don't leave are expected to absorb more and more until they stress out and quit.

pros: Enjoyed helping kids and families.
cons: Employees are not grossly underpaid and over worked.  This company means well but does not understand most of the communities they serve. They don't care about much outside of productivity hours and billing insurance. If they spent more money on paying employees a livable wage rather than extravagant parties and BS maybe the turnover rate wouldn't be so high. I recommend this job for recent college grads that still live with their parents..Oh. and if you don't mind being undervalued and bombarded with grunt paperwork, this place is for you!

review_title: Easy job, bad culture, change resistant
pros: Able to do projects of your choice. Being a non-profit there was a lot of freedom. Job was so easy and laid back that I spent 90% of my time surfing the web and learning new stuff.
cons: Very change resistant. Upper level management that has been at the company for decades believes "we've always done it this way" and will take any new suggestion you make as a big joke.

review_title: The best experience I've ever had in employment
pros:
At Guidestone, you're really making a great impact in the community in which you work. Whether you have a position providing administrative support or you're working directly with clients, you never feel like what you're doing is unimportant. 
The workplace culture is great, especially if you like having nice coworkers.
cons:
It's a non-profit, so resources are always spread thin.
If you're trying to make a lot of money, stick to the private sector.

pros: Very supportive supervisors.  Leader in the community and in the field.  Executives are smart and fiscally responsible.  Lots of room for advancement.  Innovation is encouraged.
cons: Some days can be chaotic and fast paced, but I always have the support that I need to succeed.  You will not find a better agency to work at!
